utterance: Katherine de Kleer (Caltech): So this is going a kind of different direction because I work on more on moons than on planets, but I was thinking of of this in the context of the the icy satellites and if you have um let's say a habitable environment or even life in an ocean underneath an ice shell then the bio signatures or even habitability signatures um depend heavily on understanding the ice shell and what's going on in the ice shell, what the gradient of materials or chemicals is within the ice shell, what the gradient of temperatures is. And so this goes two directions, it's the downward direction and the upward direction. In the downward direction people use, you know, the chemicals that are on the surface of the ice um and say, oh if if those chemicals can get into the ocean then the ocean is habitable. Um but to make that inference you need constraints on whether those materials can diffuse or otherwise get through the ice shell.
